organization.fullName: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

identificationModule.briefTitle: Hemodynamic Management Following Acute Traumatic Spinal Cord Injury
identificationModule.officialTitle: Hemodynamic Management Following Acute Traumatic Spinal Cord Injury: A Randomized, Controlled Trial

responsibleParty.investigatorFullName: David E. Meyer, MD, MS, FACS
responsibleParty.investigatorAffiliation: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

leadSponsor.name: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

collaborators.name: Trauma Research and Combat Casualty Care Collaborative (TRC4)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this study is to assess the effect of various hemodynamic management strategies on functional neurologic outcomes and non-neurologic adverse events in the first 5 days following acute spinal cord injury (SCI). The hemodynamic management strategies assessed include targeting a mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) goal of 85-90 mmHg, targeting a spinal cord perfusion pressure (SCPP) goal of ≥65 mmHg, or targeting normal hemodynamics, which is a MAP goal of ≥65 mmHg.

armGroups.label: Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) goal of ≥65 mmHg
interventionNames: Other: Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) goal of ≥65 mmHg

interventionNames: Other: Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) goal of 85-90 mmHg

interventions.name: Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) goal of ≥65 mmHg
interventions.description: The treatment team will maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg for the first five days following injury.
armGroupLabels: Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) goal of ≥65 mmHg

interventions.name: Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) goal of 85-90 mmHg
interventions.description: The treatment team will maintain MAP 85-90 mmHg for the first five days following injury.
armGroupLabels: Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) goal of 85-90 mmHg

interventions.name: Spinal cord perfusion pressure (SCPP) goal of ≥65 mmHg
interventions.description: The treatment team will maintain SCPP ≥65 mmHg for the first five days following injury.
armGroupLabels: Spinal cord perfusion pressure (SCPP) goal of ≥65 mmHg

primaryOutcomes.measure: The severity of a spinal cord injury (SCI) as assessed by the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) International Standards for Neurological Classification of Spinal Cord Injury (ISNCSC) motor score
primaryOutcomes.description: Upper and lower extremities will be assessed, and motor strength at each spinal cord level will be scored from 0 to 5 (0 indicates total paralysis and 5 indicates active movement against full resistance), with a maximum score of 25 for each extremity, totaling 100 for all four extremities. Total score ranges from 0 to 100, with a higher score indicating a better outcome.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Performance in activities of daily living and mobility as assessed by the Spinal Cord Independence Measure (SCIM) III score
primaryOutcomes.description: There are 3 subscales on the SCIM III: self-care (4 items, score ranging from 0-20), respiration and sphincter management (4 items, score ranging from 0-40), and mobility (9 items, score ranging from 0-40). Total score ranges from 0 to 100, with a higher score indicating a better outcome.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in motor function as assessed by the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) International Standards for Neurological Classification of Spinal Cord Injury (ISNCSC) motor score
secondaryOutcomes.description: Upper and lower extremities will be assessed, and motor strength at each spinal cord level will be scored from 0 to 5 (0 indicates total paralysis and 5 indicates active movement against full resistance), with a maximum score of 25 for each extremity, totaling 100 for all four extremities. Total score ranges from 0 to 100, with a higher score indicating a better outcome.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 6 months following injury, 12 months following injury

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in sensory function as assessed by the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) International Standards for Neurological Classification of Spinal Cord Injury (ISNCSC) sensory score
secondaryOutcomes.description: For each side of the body, 28 key sensory points will be assessed by light touch, and each area will be scored from 0 to 2 (0 indicates sensing is absent, 1 indicates sensing is altered, and 2 indicates that sensing is normal). Additionally, for each side of the body 28 key sensory points will be also be assessed by pin prick, and each area will be scored from 0 to 2 (0 indicates sensing is absent, 1 indicates sensing is altered, and 2 indicates that sensing is normal). Scores for light touch and pin prick assessments for both sides of the body will be combined, and the total score ranges from 0 to 224, with a higher score indicating a better outcome.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 6 months following injury, 12 months following injury

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in performance in activities of daily living and mobility as assessed by the Spinal Cord Independence Measure (SCIM) III score
secondaryOutcomes.description: There are 3 subscales on the SCIM III: self-care (4 items, score ranging from 0-20), respiration and sphincter management (4 items, score ranging from 0-40), and mobility (9 items, score ranging from 0-40). Total score ranges from 0 to 100, with a higher score indicating a better outcome.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 6 months following injury, 12 months following injury

secondaryOutcomes.description: Number of ICU-free days = \[30 days - ICU length of stay in days\]. Patients with ICU length of stay \>30 days will be assigned a value of zero ICU-free days.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Duration of time (hours) receiving goal caloric requirements by enteric nutrition
Number of participants developing a central line-associated blood stream infection
secondaryOutcomes.description: Blood stream infection is defined as bacteremia confirmed by blood culture in the presence of a central venous catheter.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline to hospital discharge or 30 days, whichever comes first

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of participants developing a pneumothorax from central venous catheter insertion
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline to hospital discharge or 30 days, whichever comes first

secondaryOutcomes.description: Pneumonia is defined as 10,000 colony forming units (cfu)/milliliter (mL) on bronchioalveolar lavage or mini bronchioalveolar lavage, or clinical diagnosis of pneumonia with subsequent antibiotic treatment.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline to hospital discharge or 30 days, whichever comes first

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of participants developing acute kidney injury using the Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage kidney disease (RIFLE) criteria
secondaryOutcomes.description: Acute kidney injury using the RIFLE criteria is defined as a 50% increase in serum creatinine from baseline or urine output \<0.5 mL/h for 6 hours.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline to hospital discharge or 30 days, whichever comes first
Baseline to hospital discharge or 30 days, whichever comes first

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Traumatic spinal cord injury

Exclusion Criteria:

* Patients with an injury from a trauma that penetrates the spinal cord (i.e., gunshot or knife wound resulting in cord transection)
* Preexisting neurologic or spinal cord injury
* Severe traumatic brain injury as measured by a best resuscitated Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of \<8 at 24 hours following injury
* Presence of traumatic injuries that preclude spine surgery within 24 hours of presentation
* Concomitant injury/illness requiring targeted blood pressure management (e.g., injury to the aorta, aortic dissection, hemorrhagic stroke)
* Preexisting history of neuromotor disorders (i.e., cerebral palsy, Parkinson disease, etc.)
* Not expected to survive \>24h
* Cord transection identified by radiologist and agreed upon by the spine surgery team
* Injury below spinal cord level L1
* Prisoners
* Pregnant women
